review_title: Do not recommend; other universities treat their employees better
job_title: Senior Academic Coordinator in Washington, DC
pros: When I was there, mental health counseling was provided for free as a benefit through One Medical, in addition to free One Medical membership. Not sure if that is included anymore.
cons: When the pandemic hit, they forced departments to volunteer one or more lower-level staff members to serve as the guards who were checking people at building entrances during the pandemic shutdown. You could either accept the role or go on unpaid leave for about 4 months. You weren't paid extra and you were expected to perform your normal job in addition to 20 hours of guarding the entrances. Absolutely horrific treatment of staff. Do not recommend working here. The pay is also one of the lowest among the universities in the area, and instead of providing merit raises, everyone gets standard 2% raises depending on the whim of the finance office that year. If you want to get a real raise, you have to go out and get a competing offer, and they will only match, not beat, your competing offer.

review_title: Stay away if you’re a person of color who cares about equity and justice.
pros: Surrounding areas are pretty to walk around.
cons: Awful and not updated buildings, elitist culture, white supremacy seeping into workplace, awful pay range even for master level positions. I don’t know how it is in other departments but the GUMC is rife with micro aggressions, power hoarding and high egos, and many of what is considered white supremacist characteristics ARE present! No growth mindset. Employee feedback given to higher management and leadership is considered threatening. Lots of folks who are not effective communicators and have zero skills in introspection and accountability. Stay away from this place if you are BIPOC identifying, intellectually people talk about equity and diversity but they’re not translated into practice which creates an extremely toxic culture. You will most likely end up being told to educate your white or white appearing colleagues for their ignorance. Very quick to placate concerns to silence you but doesn’t really solve the issues brought up.

review_title: GU - Great company to work for
pros: Georgetown has a fantastic community, full of professors, competent staff, and caring people. The main reason to work here is to take advantage of the tuition benefit, which now takes two years of full-time work to earn. If you are not using the tuition benefit, there is no reason to work here. The salary is just too low. Benefits are also outstanding (retirement and health care).
cons: Pay is low and advancement opportunities, if they materialize, take a long time. Also, the tuition benefit, which is the whole reason to work here, is hard to use because the pay is so low, and graduate tuition is counted as taxable income.

review_title: A friendly place to work, but ultimately an isolating experience
pros: IF you like Georgetown, then the location is great. You don't have to travel too far to get to Wisconsin and M St, and Glover Park actually has some good places to grab lunch on your break. The salary is quite competitive, especially for research assistants who are still in grad school. Since the economists who work there are also teaching or doing some research with Georgetown University, they're very open about helping you with your work and are willing to take the time to explain either how to calculate certain things, which software to use, or even how to set up your Excel sheet correctly if you're new.
cons: As a person who enjoys a bit more liveliness, the office can be just a total downer. Everyone stays in their office the entire day and it's so quiet you can hear the air coming out of the vents. Not only that, but research assistants are put into a little nook in the middle of the floor with no windows, natural light, or connectivity. One of the desks just meets in the center where the walls are coming in, and if you suffer from claustrophobia you might freak out. Those who are there put their earbuds in all day and don't have much to say.

review_title: Good work-life balance.  Excellent culture. Terrible management.
pros: Work-life balance; two weeks off at Christmas; 10% salary contribution to 401K if employee vests 3%; Room to grow -- can change jobs/functions within University very easily; Great place for self-starters; Job security; Tuition Benefit is outstanding.  Good place to get a free Master's, have a couple of babies, lay low, skill up, and then get back into the private sector.  Prestigious institution -- name recognition.  Always intellectual engagement opportunities.
cons: Administration poorly run.  If you want to get things done -- you might find it frustrating to work with a large number of colleagues that treat their positions as clocking in and clocking out.  Many are unmotivated to think creatively and strategically.  There is little incentive to be responsible for your work.  Abysmal merit increases, never more than 2% -- every other year they freeze salary increase.  Departmental budgets are continually absorb cuts; seemingly, there are always financial troubles.

review_title: Over ten years I've watched the once very special, collegiate quality of working in  this community deteriorate.
job_title: Public Relations, Communications in Washington, DC
pros: Good retirement package. And, yes, it still draws really great, gifted, and dedicated people who can be a real joy to work among. Why they seem much less likely to hire these peoople into jobs at the supervisor/administrator level is a puzzle.
cons:
Departments that should be keenly focused on providing good systems of service more often are so difficult to work with that it is a huge frustration to work with them--especially those involved with the smooth financial operation of business affairs--something you would expect a model operation at a school trying to promote a leading edge School of Business like McDonough. 
As has been written before, the administrative level makes decisions and policies that most often block rather than facilitate the organization's healthy growth into a 21st century management model.

pros: Great team and decent pay
cons: Lack of growth opportunities for employees

pros:
Very good for women seeking a family-friendly environment, lots of room for promotion.  There is very little parking though, so it makes it difficult to commute.  Shuttle buses are available between Dupont Circle and Rosslyn Metro Stops.  The campus is small but vernice and you will find that you get to know people quickly.  

Generally if your work is good you will get recognition in the form of promotion or compensation.  Although for the cost of living the stipend is low, students have other advantages.  One is that professors are available often on an "open door" policy to answer any questions/concerns.
cons: D.C. is a very expensive city; salaries are average.  Many students must get second jobs to make ends meet or they have spousal support.  However Georgetown is well recognized in the research community so job opportunities are not too difficult to come by after graduation.  Often students complete their post-docs at NIH, National Academies of Science, or other prestigious institutions.  The only other down-side is that funding is always tight.  All students are required to write and submit at least one grant during their training.  On the flip side, this is good training for the future life as a scientist.

pros: The students and faculty are wonderful, and in general I think people are committed to their work (certainly they are not doing it for the money!)  Most people are pleasant to work with, and overall it is a friendly place and less pretentious than I expected. There are an endless stream of activities that staff can usually attend, so many it's really overwhelming. Good benefits.
cons: The pay is too low for DC and raises have been pitiful in recent years. There is no cost-of-living raise, even though the university seems to have no problem affording new programs or new buildings. I know sometimes projects are simply earmarked this way, but it's pretty obvious that keeping a good staff is a low priority. There are a lot of settled long-timers, but turnover tends to be high for younger staff. It is quite difficult to physically get to as well, and expensive to live nearby.

review_title: Friendly Colleagues, Menial Jobs, Beware of "Free Tuition" Pitfalls
pros:
- Diverse work environment and ability to attend on-campus events (lectures, classes etc)
- Good benefits to go with a modest salary
- Free tuition after continuous employment of at least 12 months
cons:
- Modest salaries (though compensated by free tuition after a year of working full-time)
- Work was not very challenging for someone with advanced skills
- Little or no career advancement opportunities (despite being a large organization with numerous open job postings, there's very little effort to have employees switch departments in case of re-orgs or staff layoffs).
- The tuition assistance benefit is a great employee benefit on paper. However, there is a lot of fine print, including a one-year waiting period. Worst experience of my tenure was being laid-off right after being accepted into a top-tier graduate program at the university. It meant that I had to pay the tuition out of pocket.
- Management handled the layoffs process poorly.

review_title: Overall Work Experience as a Student Front Desk Assistant at the MBA Career Center
job_title: MBA Career Center Front Desk Student Worker Assistant in Washington, DC
pros: Great co-workers! I love the people who work at this office because they are all so friendly and helpful, both the students and faculty. The faculty go out of their way to get to know the student workers and I really appreciate it. The students that come into the career center are always very appreciative of the front desk workers, so it is nice to be noticed and appreciated by so many people!
cons: The first shift starts at 8 am, and it is very busy with a lot to do in order to open the office so early in the morning. You also do not get paid extra for doing all of the extra work of opening the office.

pros: Friendly people and small working environment made for a personable atmosphere, not to mention when life stuff happens, they're very accommodating. Plus, being on the campus every day was just an amazing experience. Also: after one year working at the university, you can enroll at the university for a master's program that's fully reimbursed.
cons: There is a huge bureaucracy at the university. Also, and this is perhaps the most disconcerting thing, full-time employees who are staff (not faculty nor upper-level administration) get treated second-class at times in terms of salary and salary raises. Many of my colleagues took advantage of the tuition reimbursement and then left for a much better paying job after graduating with an MBA or other master's degree. Unless you are a professor, this is likely not a long-term job destination.

review_title: University culture is problematic for staff
pros: Nice location. Pays more than other universities in the area for comparable positions. Tuition benefits. My Kaiser Permanente health insurance was amazing.
cons: Very little consistency between departments. My supervisor had very little regard for my actual job description, and along with needing to chip in with a number of tasks over my pay grade on short notice, I found myself running personal errands for my supervisor, helping with their Doctoral dissertation research and even had to type up their Dissertation cover page and work on citations. I was an Executive assistant for Student Affairs--- not this person's personal assistant. I felt that I could not refuse to work on these tasks without damaging my annual review and position in the office. The University charged much too much for parking (even though they have a garage) and a year of taking Metro was actually cheaper than paying for a year of parking.  Problems within the department (when an employee was stealing, for instance) were not dealt with in a consistent way that clearly involved HR because the department wanted to keep the incident quiet from the students.

pros:
If you work at Georgetown for one year, you will be eligible for full tuition reimbursement for any Georgetown degree or certificate program you want to pursue. This is an amazing opportunity for anyone needing help to finance and Part time MBA program or a master's program or PhD program. 
Excellent benefits (medical, retirement contribution matching, vacation days). 
Access to a world-class faculty who can help you advance your career.  Very supportive and friendly colleagues.
cons: The role bears a lot of responsibility and requires a lot of diligence and commitment. Academia tends to be a very political environment to work in (lots of red tape and egos).

pros: Good compensation and excellent benefits.  Very flexible with working hours.  Most of the faculty are great to work with.  An excellent job to have while pursuing a part-time education.
cons: Limited to no possibility for advancement up the ladder;  openings are very rare and they go to friends of the boss.  University Human Resources is incompetent and imposes nonsensical policies (e.g. insisting that we be hourly and not salaried employees) that serve no one's interest.  Some faculty can be very abusive, and you really don't have the power to say no to any faculty requests, no matter how expensive they are.

pros:
- Flexible and autonomous work and schedule (for senior staff)
- High impact work that really matters and makes a difference
- Unbelievably good benefits, I mean, an automatic 10% contribution to your 401k? Unheard of. 
- Chance to work with and mentor some of the smartest, most dedicated students in the country
- An awesome place to build your rolodex - connecting with incredible thought leaders, politicians, and Fortune 500 execs are your "everyday lunch meetings"
- Ego-less, nice, friendly, committed and honest co-workers with integrity in spades
- Beautiful campus, amazing location
cons:
- IT system is a bit of a mess
- Onboarding process for new staff is non-existant
- Heavily siloed and disjointed
- Internal processes (i.e. hiring, HR, finance, etc) is beyond antiquated --- needs a serious reboot
- Salaries not great

pros: Georgetown has a very flexible environment.  It's very relaxed. Free education !! This is honestly the best part, you can complete certificates or degrees as long as you've worked there at least a year.  Amazing match on 401k plan.
cons: Low pay. The University even had a salary freeze out in place during the crisis.  They don't even give a real inflation raise.  If you are looking to get a raise this is not the place as you will never get one unless you transfer departments.  One year we got a 0.75% raise ...

review_title: Family Friendly with excellent life-work balance.
pros:
Georgetown has great benefits (medical, holidays, vacation), flexible schedule for many jobs, friendly people who are happy to come to work, stable work environment with little to no layoffs.  There are often impressive guest speakers on a variety of topics.
The university has been around almost as long as the country itself.
cons:
No actual raises in 10 years.  The "merit" salary increase pool is about the same or less than COLA.
Guest speakers sessions with the most interest fill up in about 1 minute.
With such a long heritage, and no layoffs, many inefficient systems, processes, and departments stay around longer than they should.

review_title: unless you are tenured faculty, stay away from Georgetown.
pros: Georgetown has great retirement benefits, they will match up to 7% by just allocating 3% of your salary to the plan.  You are also eligible for free tuition after 1 year of work as long as you get into a program
cons: Georgetown has a 2 class system of employees; those that have to follow rules and protocol (staff) and faculty who are allowed to be rude, break rules, and in some instances Georgetown will even cover when the law is broken by faculty members.

review_title: Laid-back atmosphere, nice people, but low salary and the evil, dreaded PTO (e.g., no sick leave)
pros: People are nice and it's laid back
cons: Wages are quite low and they offer no paid sick leave (just crappy PTO)

review_title: Excellent environment with a blend of engaging academics/practitioners stifled by stagnant administrative staff
pros: Excellent work environment respectful of people and professionalism.  Great benefits with time given for worklife and continuing education.  Really smart people working in key areas who engage and appreciate their staff.  Collaborative environment where contributions are praised and encouraged.
cons: Senior administrative staff are 9-5 with little more and no innovation.  Abundance of paper-based procedures to get simple things done.  Turnover in Senior Executive roles without appropriate succession planning has disjointed some parts of operations.

review_title: Medical Center is a Nightmare - Main Campus much better!
pros: Great benefits - especially the tuition benefits. Experience at GU highly depends on department/school you land in. Main campus had a much better culture than medical center so I'd advise staying away from the med center.
cons: Low salary, bureaucratic, zero training coupled with high expectations to get acclimated quickly, not supportive of employees who are also students, poor communication amongst departments and managers to employees, thankless job that can wear morale down because no matter how many hours you put in you're still failing.

pros: Job security, good benefits (including full tuition after one year's service), generally intelligent, committed colleagues (depends on unit), smart students, prestigious organization
cons: Pay hardly increases (less that 2%/year for even the best performers--some years is flat), no cost of living adjustment, little incentive or possibility to move up in the organization,  little incentive for professional growth (it has to come from you), widespread disregard for staff by faculty and upper administration, including the Provost.

pros: Competitive benefits, growth oriented culture, great conversations, open people, a network of friends.
cons: Unreasonably silo-ed, physically and mentally removed from the surrounding community, 'friendly' nature has some advantages, but becomes VERY cliquey which makes it really difficult to break into the culture or to spread new ideas in the organization.

pros: Good place to work as far as stability and benefits are okay.
cons: They don't support the regular hourly staff. If you are only hourly staff of color don't expect to go any further. They only promote those that they like and can probably manipulate. Raises are 33 cents nothing over a $1.00. You will eventually feel stuck in a dead end job.

review_title: Great benefits, extremely poor pay that's way below federal standards for some positions.
pros: Good benefits package to continue education and to build funds for retirement. Depending on where dependents attend school, GU may cover the tuition cost.  Great working environment for entry level positions.
cons: 1.) The pay is way below FLSA. 2.) The cost of living pay is not enough to assist with keeping up with inflation. 3.) Also, hourly pay or salaries are not equitable across the university. For instance, a budget in one department can pay more or less for the same position in another department.

pros: Great atmosphere for learning. Graduate programs in the School of Continuing Studies are designed to prepare students to become industry leaders. Practitioners bring today's business challenges to the classroom, which creates dynamic class conversations. Plenty of meaningful internship opportunities in the D.C. region, which allows students to gain experience and make valuable connections.
cons: The School of Continuing Studies is a modern and well-equipped building, which is conveniently located near metro, but it does take students away from the traditional campus atmosphere and environment.

pros: Tuition benefit. Great 401K and insurance. Welcomes the celebration of faith and worship on campus. Opportunity to hear great speakers, politicians, and celebrities speak on various topics.
cons: Employees severely underpaid. Difficult to live with DC high cost of living. Location not metro accessible. They offer a shuttle from two metro stations, but the shuttles only drop off in one area which may require a long walk to assigned office after shuttle drop off.  Lack of diversity in professional staff but the majority of low wage positions are held by people of color. Students of color feel under-supported and have held multiple protest. Administration has yet to make noticeable changes.

job_title: Coordinator to Director Throughout Tenure in Washington, DC
pros:
Colleagues. Programming. Great retirement plan. Tuition reimbursement. Mission. Sense of purpose and completion. 
You can take on as much as you can handle and they let you run with projects. A lot more responsibility at a young age early in my career.
cons: Salaries are terrible. Once you are in the door there are minimal raises so they lose talent. It's easier to leave (or switch campuses) and then come back with a higher paying job than having grown through the ranks.

review_title: Very satisfied with my experience working for this company. Lots of flexibility in research projects and opportunities.
pros: I have plenty of opportunities for professional growth and development, such as attending trainings to broaden my skill set and the ability to co-design and oversee research projects. I enjoy being able to take leadership of my projects. Good time off procedure, and lots of holidays since the university is religious and observes national holidays.
cons: Sometimes the bureaucracy at the university can be frustrating. It often takes a long time to get things approved, especially salary increases.

review_title: Needs strong top-down command authority and structure, more decision-making, less politics.
pros:
Free tuition, name recognition, ok benefits, good environment with respect to family life.
Most management is accepting of families, kids, and a home life.
cons:
Internal politics interfere with everything.
Lack of good executive management decisions.
Lack of consistent direction by management -- too many false starts and dropped priorities.

review_title: Good experience in a casual position
job_title: Receptionist / Administrative Assistant  in Washington, DC
pros: Relaxed athmosphere, nice location & surroundings, colleagues easy to work with, I was able to work the number of hours agreed on contract (i.e. no cancelled shifts or overtime requirements), managers were friendly & respectful. My ratings (predominantly neutral / 3) reflect the casual nature of my work: I had no need to consider career advancement, senior leadership, etc. On the other hand, I never had any negative experiences either, such as arrogant or rude senior managers, etc. All in all, going to work at Georgetown was easy and problem-free.
cons: Difficult to find parking, nearest metro stop far from campus.

pros: I really enjoyed my two years as a Fellow at Georgetown University Law Center. The contacts I made were outstanding, there were lots of opportunities to engage in all sorts of intellectual events and other social and sporting activities. The legal projects I worked on were prestigious and involved interesting travel. University has good leave policies and benefits such as gym, cheap cafeteria, good working from home policy in my unit.
cons: Lack of potential to move upwards (all academic jobs like this at the moment). Academic bosses not necessarily good managers, but were well meaning.

review_title: Institute for Reproductive Health: Good place to get a footing in SRH
pros: (This review is specifically for IRH:) Great people who care about the mission. Flexibility to help with projects outside of your portfolio if interested in the topic area. Celebrates milestones for each staff member, including birthdays, baby showers, and graduations.
cons: (This review is specifically for IRH:)  Pay bands are very firm, and upward progress within organization is slow. From entry level, the next possible promotion is after a master's degree or four years of work at the organization. As with most nonprofits, not quite enough staff for the work, but they're adding more soon.

pros: Flexible working schedule, as my position was part time. Occasional free lunch, looks good on resume, many free and interesting events and lectures to attend on campus.
cons: Often felt left out by permanent staff and was never invited to attend departmental functions/events I helped coordinate (while permanent staff attended). My suggestions for improvements were never acknowledged, and after 6 months of dedicated service, no one had the decency to inform me of when my temporary assignment was going to end. I received a phone call notifying me that my assignment was over and that I didn't have to return to work the next day.

pros:
- Fantastic networking
- Really dedicated people in junior to mid-level positions
cons:
- Top level staff very disconnected from the actual do-ers and students
- High staff turn over on the junior to mid-level
- Staff not held to any standards and many take advantage of this
- Pretty much any student can get in here- need better academic standards (they focus on quantity rather than quality in admissions)

review_title: Some great people, lots of laudable goals - both of which suffer at the hands of management either mediocre or hostile.
pros: Generally good benefits, decent compensation for many positions. Always a lot going on. Being on campus has a lot of perks - fun events, free food, an energetic environment. Shuttles to metro stations not bad (though they run infrequently).
cons: Your experience depends almost entirely on your supervisor, and many of them - especially middle management - are horrendous. Financial constraints on the University make pay raises few and far between and there are no clear pathways for career advancement for most positions.

review_title: Good place to intern and learn about law
pros: The intern coordinator is super-flexible, supportive, and willing to help. She often sets up a lot of perks for the interns. The attorneys are friendly, very smart, and looking to engage you as much as possible. Overall, very laid-back and comfortable environment.
cons: The quality of investigative interns can seriously hurt the attorneys and their work from semester to semester, but they have more students on hand during the school year as well.

review_title: Opportunities abound if you're willing to wait.
pros:
-Free tuition to a top university after working for a year (pending acceptance of course), including certification courses.
-Perks and discounts to local businesses available for university employees.
-Historic neighborhood.
cons:
-Pay is low compared to what you could get from similar universities or non-profit organizations and management doesn't give raises liberally.
-Favoritism and preference is always given to alumni or current students. Experienced candidates are frequently passed over in favor of new GU grads to help drive up the school's placement statistics.
-It takes an awful lot to get fired.

job_title: Grants Project Assistant in Washington, DC
pros:
I was a student worker who worked part-time during the year and full-time in the summer. 
- really great place as a student employee. 
- able to mold my work hours around my classes
- felt like I was an integral part of the team, even just doing admin work
- was given more responsibility as I progressed in the role
cons:
- communication between departments is VERY slow and time consuming
- mixed bag on management. I had a very positive experience, but I know others who didn't

pros:
Administrators and department heads are supportive and recognize entry-level employees as individuals. 

Jobs in Residential Living offer the opportunity to develop a wide variety of skills and provide many avenues for advancement.

pros: Great location. Lots of events and opportunities to grow your professional network. Intellectual enrichment is only inhibited by your own motivation.

review_title: No room for advancement; failure to live up to stated value of organization
pros:
- Working with students often means working with highly intelligent, very idealistic young people who will appreciate it when you trust them with real responsibility
- Tuition assistance
cons:
Based on my experience as an administrator and middle manager at Georgetown for eight years:

- There is little or no opportunity for advancement within each department or the University as a whole, even for employees who have earned excellent performance reviews, have used their tuition benefits to increase their education, etc.

- There is a consistent preference, across departments, to fill higher-level positions with outside talent, rather than through promoting talented people from within the University. Over time this becomes a major disincentive for employees either (1) to remain at the University long term or (2) to work at their maximum level of ability. It also often results in management that does not understand the special problems inherent in dealing with students, student employees, parents, academic departments, etc. It also results in departments with ZERO institutional memory; so that, for example, policies that failed in the past will be introduced by the leadership, who are unaware that those policies have already been attempted--and then rescinded when they proved overcostly or counterproductive.

- In many departments, the managerial strategy seems to be one of divide-and-rule: A handful of people at the top are paid exceptionally well (to ensure their loyalty) while everyone below is paid wages far below what they would make for the same work, even at other colleges and not-for-profits.

- A pervasive feature of Georgetown's professional culture -- quietly conceded by many staff -- is a cynical disregard for the University's own stated values. I once had an very-very-upper-level administrator inform me that my job was to get as much work out of my student employees as possible for as little money as possible. When I objected that this approach was not consistent with the Catholic values that Georgetown espoused, the response was laughter, and a stern command to "tow the company line." (Until that moment, I thought only villainous cartoon bosses like Mr. Burns gave orders like "tow the company line.")
